Cedric,

Appreciate your reference to "migration" as one of the (cost) 
co=
mponents of technology change.

When performing a cost/benefit analysis the=
 availability of a 
thoughtful (well-engineered) migration strategy certain=
ly helps 
reduce the "cost".  (It would not be considered a benefit - since=
 
migration is fundamentally a "cost" component.) 

Another often overlooke=
d cost component is "legal".  It was 
interesting to consult at one recent =
company and note they  
considered themselves indemnified for using JDK 1.3=
 by virtue of its 
distribution with their licensed Application Server and =
IDE 
environment.  In other words, you were not authorized to use a v. 
1.3=
 JDK other than the one distributed with the licensed IDE 
installed by the=
ir infrastructure support team on your desktop.

(Note: The same was true f=
or JUnit and Struts.  Since JUnit/Struts 
was distributed by the licensed v=
endor with the IDE it could be 
used.  No upgrades allowed!)

*** End of Re=
sponse ***  ... Opinions follow.

While thinking more about JavaDoc annotat=
ions; it seems (to me) 
there is a fundamental contextual difference betwee=
n using an 
annotation as a "marker" (@deprecated with JDK or @excludeClass=
 with 
TestUtil) to be interpreted outside of method invocation and using a=
 
JavaDoc annotation to alter runtime execution.  (This might be 
considere=
d similar to the distinction between using an Interface as 
a loosely-coupl=
ed marker [to overcome single-class inheritance] vs. 
an Interface to force=
 tight [fragile] coupling between artifacts.)

So - what I'm having trouble=
 cost justifying is introducing a 
runtime influencing technology that simp=
ly is a stylistic 
programming change - from "test" to "@Test".  There is n=
o value-add 
here.  Right?  No additional value to customers and no additio=
nal 
value to developers.  It is simply style.

Or, am I fundamentally miss=
ing something.

_Marvin
